original.title: Book IV: The Four Virtues
original.preview: Adeimantus: How would you answer, Socrates, if a person were to say that you are making these people miserable?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: How would you answer, Socrates, if a person were to say that you are making these people miserable, and that they are the cause of their own unhappiness; the city in fact belongs to them, but they are none the better for it?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Whereas other men acquire lands, and build large and handsome houses, and have everything handsome about them, offering sacrifices to the gods on their own account; moreover, they have gold and silver, and all that is usual among the favourites of fortune.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But our poor citizens are no better than mercenaries who are quartered in the city and are always mounting guard.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, and you may add that they are only fed, and not paid in addition to their food, like other men; and therefore they cannot, if they would, take a journey of pleasure; they have no money to spend on luxuries.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But let us suppose all this to be included in the charge.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You mean to ask what will be our answer?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Our answer will be that our guardians may very likely be the happiest of men; but that our aim in founding the State was not the disproportionate happiness of any one class, but the greatest happiness of the whole.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We thought that in a State which is ordered with a view to the good of the whole we should be most likely to find Justice.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Suppose that we were painting a statue, and some one came up to us and said, Why do you not put the most beautiful colours on the most beautiful parts of the body—the eyes ought to be purple, but you have made them black.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: To him we might fairly answer: Sir, you would not surely have us beautify the eyes to such a degree that they are no longer eyes; consider rather whether, by giving this and the other features their due proportion, we make the whole beautiful.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I think that you are quite right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There seem to be two causes of the deterioration of the arts.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What are they?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Wealth and poverty.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: How do they act?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When a potter becomes rich, will he any longer take the same pains with his art?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He will grow more and more indolent and careless, and become a worse potter. But, on the other hand, if he has no money, and cannot provide himself tools or instruments, he will not work equally well himself.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is evident.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here, then, is a discovery of new evils against which the guardians will have to watch—wealth and poverty; the one is the parent of luxury and indolence, and the other of meanness and viciousness, and both of discontent.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But still I should like to know, Socrates, how our city will be able to go to war, especially against an enemy who is rich and powerful, if deprived of the sinews of war.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There would certainly be a difficulty in going to war with one such enemy; but there is no difficulty where there are two of them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: How so?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the first place, if we have to fight, our side will be trained warriors fighting against an army of rich men.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And do you not suppose that a single boxer who was perfect in his art would easily be a match for two stout and well-to-do gentlemen who were not boxers?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Hardly, if they came upon him at once.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What, not if he were able to run away and then turn and strike at the one who first came up? And supposing he were to do this several times under the heat of a scorching sun, might he not overturn more than one stout personage?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly, there would be nothing wonderful in that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we may assume that our athletes will be able to fight with two or three times their own number?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I agree with you, for I think you right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Any city, however small, is in fact divided into two, one the city of the poor, the other of the rich; these are at war with one another.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if you deal with them as many, and give the wealth or power of the one to the others, you will always have a great many friends and not many enemies.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What will be the best limit for our rulers to fix when they are considering the size of the State?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What limit would you propose?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I would allow the State to increase so far as is consistent with unity; that, I think, is the proper limit.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Education and nurture: If our citizens are well educated, and grow into sensible men, they will easily see their way through all these matters.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Also, the State, if once started well, moves with accumulating force like a wheel. For good nurture and education implant good constitutions, and these good constitutions taking root in a good education improve more and more.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very possibly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This is the point to which, above all, the attention of our rulers should be directed—that music and gymnastic be preserved in their original form, and no innovation made.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For any musical innovation is full of danger to the whole State, and ought to be prohibited. When modes of music change, the fundamental laws of the State always change with them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, and you may add my suffrage to that opinion.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then our guardians must lay the foundations of their fortress in music?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, the lawlessness of which you speak too easily steals in.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, in the form of amusement; and at first sight it appears harmless.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Why, yes, and there is no harm; were it not that little by little this spirit of licence, finding a home, imperceptibly penetrates into manners and customs.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Whence, issuing with greater force, it invades contracts between man and man, and from contracts goes on to laws and constitutions, in utter recklessness, ending at last by an overthrow of all rights, private as well as public.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is that true?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is my belief.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But where, amid all this, is justice? Now that our city has been made habitable, light a candle and search, and get your brother and Polemarchus and the rest of our friends to help.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Nonsense! Did you not promise to search yourself, saying that for you not to help justice in her need would be an impiety?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I do not deny that I said so, and as you remind me, I will be as good as my word; but you must join.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: We will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, then, I hope to make the discovery in this way: I mean to begin with the assumption that our State, if rightly ordered, is perfect.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is most certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And being perfect, is therefore wise and valiant and temperate and just.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is likewise clear.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First among the virtues found in the State, wisdom comes into view. The State which we have been describing is said to be wise as being good in counsel.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And good counsel is clearly a kind of knowledge, for not by ignorance, but by knowledge, do men counsel well.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is the knowledge of the carpenter; but is that the sort of knowledge which gives a city the title of wise and good in counsel?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly not; that would only give a city the reputation of skill in carpentering.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is there any knowledge in our recently founded State among any of the citizens which advises, not about any particular thing in the State, but about the whole, and considers how a State can best deal with itself and with other States?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There certainly is.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what is knowledge, and among whom is it found?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: It is the knowledge of the guardians, and found among those whom we were just now describing as perfect guardians.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Thus, then, the nature and place in the State of one of the four virtues has somehow or other been discovered.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And, in my humble opinion, very satisfactorily discovered.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Again, there is no difficulty in seeing the nature of courage; and in what part that quality resides which gives the name of courageous to the State.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Every one who calls any State courageous or cowardly, will be thinking of the part which fights and goes out to war on the State's behalf.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I mean that courage is a kind of salvation—of the opinion respecting things to be feared, what they are and of what nature, which the law implants through education.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You know that dyers, when they want to dye wool for making the true sea-purple, begin by selecting their white colour first; this they prepare and dress with much care and pains, in order that the white ground may take the purple hue in full perfection.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I know that they have a washed-out and ridiculous appearance when the ground has not been duly prepared.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then now you will understand what our object was in selecting our soldiers, and educating them in music and gymnastic; we were contriving influences which would prepare them to take the dye of the laws in perfection.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I agree, for I suppose that you mean to exclude mere uninstructed courage, such as that of a wild beast or of a slave.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Most certainly. Two virtues remain to be discovered in the State—first temperance, and then justice which is the end of our search.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, can we find justice without troubling ourselves about temperance?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I do not know how that can be accomplished, nor do I desire that justice should be brought to light and temperance lost sight of; and therefore I wish that you would do me the favour of considering temperance first.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Certainly, I should not be justified in refusing your request. Temperance, I replied, is the ordering or controlling of certain pleasures and desires; this is curiously enough implied in the saying of 'a man being his own master.'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No doubt.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is something ridiculous in the expression 'master of himself'; for the master is also the servant and the servant the master.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The meaning is, I believe, that in the human soul there is a better and also a worse principle; and when the better has the worse under control, then a man is said to be master of himself.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, there is reason in that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Temperance is unlike courage and wisdom, each of which resides in a part only. Temperance extends to the whole, and runs through all the notes of the scale, and produces a harmony of the weaker and the stronger and the middle class.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I entirely agree with you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so we may consider three out of the four virtues to have been discovered in our State. The last of those qualities which make a state virtuous must be justice, if we only knew what that was.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The inference is obvious.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The time then has arrived, Glaucon, when, like huntsmen, we should surround the cover, and look sharp that justice does not steal away, and pass out of sight and escape us.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Would that I could! but you should regard me rather as a follower who has just eyes enough to see what you show him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Offer up a prayer with me and follow.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I will, but you must show me the way.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here is no path, and the wood is dark and perplexing; still we must push on.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here I saw something: Halloo! I begin to perceive a track, and I believe that the quarry will not escape.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Good news.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Truly, we are stupid fellows. At the beginning of our enquiry, ages ago, there was justice tumbling out at our feet, and we never saw her.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You remember the original principle which we were always laying down at the foundation of the State, that one man should practise one thing only, the thing to which his nature was best adapted—now justice is this principle or a part of it.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, we often said that one man should do one thing only.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Further, we affirmed that justice was doing one's own business, and not being a busybody; we said so again and again.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, we said so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When the trader, the auxiliary, and the guardian each do their own business, that is justice, and will make the city just.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I agree with you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Must we not acknowledge that in each of us there are the same principles and habits which there are in the State?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There is no difficulty in understanding this.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But the question is not quite so easy when we proceed to ask whether these principles are three or one; whether we learn with one part of our nature, are angry with another, and with a third part desire the satisfaction of our natural appetites.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, there lies the difficulty.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The same thing clearly cannot act or be acted upon in the same part or in relation to the same thing at the same time, in contrary ways.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we may fairly assume that they are two, and that they differ from one another; the one with which man reasons, we may call the rational principle of the soul, the other, with which he loves and hungers and thirsts, may be termed the irrational or appetitive.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, we may fairly assume them to be different.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what of passion, or spirit? Is it a third, or akin to one of the preceding?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I should be inclined to say—akin to desire.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is a story which I remember to have heard: Leontius, coming up one day from the Piraeus, observed some dead bodies lying on the ground at the place of execution. He felt a desire to see them, and also a dread and abhorrence of them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For a time he struggled and covered his eyes, but at length the desire got the better of him; and forcing them open, he ran up to the dead bodies, saying, 'Look, ye wretches, take your fill of the fair sight.'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I have heard the story myself.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The moral of the tale is, that anger at times goes to war with desire, as though they were two distinct things.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes; that is the meaning.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so, after much tossing, we have reached land, and are fairly agreed that the same principles which exist in the State exist also in the individual, and that they are three in number.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Must we not then infer that the individual is wise in the same way, and in virtue of the same quality which makes the State wise?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the individual will be acknowledged by us to be just in the same way in which the State is just?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That follows, of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The just man does not permit the several elements within him to interfere with one another, or any of them to do the work of others—he sets in order his own inner life, and is his own master and his own law, and at peace with himself.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When he has bound together the three principles within him, which may be compared to the higher, lower, and middle notes of the scale, then he proceeds to act, always thinking and calling that which preserves and co-operates with this harmonious condition, just and good action.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: You have said the exact truth, Socrates.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then virtue is the health and beauty and well-being of the soul, and vice the disease and weakness and deformity of the same.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And do not good practices lead to virtue, and evil practices to vice?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Assuredly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Still our old question of the comparative advantage of justice and injustice has not been answered: Which is the more profitable?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: In my judgment, Socrates, the question has now become ridiculous. We know that, when the bodily constitution is gone, life is no longer endurable; and shall we be told that when the very essence of the vital principle is undermined and corrupted, life is still worth having?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, the question is ridiculous. Still, as we are near the spot at which we may see the truth in the clearest manner with our own eyes, let us not faint by the way.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The argument seems to have reached a height from which, as from some tower of speculation, a man may look down and see that virtue is one, but that the forms of vice are innumerable; there being four special ones which are deserving of note.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There appear to be as many forms of the soul as there are distinct forms of the State.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How many?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There are five of the State, and five of the soul. The first is that which we have been describing, and which may be said to have two names, monarchy and aristocracy, accordingly as rule is exercised by one distinguished man or by many.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

modern.title: Book IV: Finding the Four Virtues
modern.preview: Adeimantus: How would you respond if someone said you're making these guardians miserable?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: How would you respond if someone said you're making these guardians miserable? They're supposed to own the city, but they don't benefit from it at all.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Meanwhile, other people buy land, build nice houses, throw parties, and have gold and silver—all the stuff that supposedly makes you happy.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But our citizens are basically just unpaid soldiers stuck on guard duty.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, and they can't even take vacations or buy nice things because they have no money.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Let's say that's all part of the complaint.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You want to know how we'd respond to that?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Look, our guardians might actually be the happiest people around. But that's not the point—we weren't trying to make one group super happy. We were designing a state where everyone together is as happy as possible.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We figured that in a state organized for everyone's good, we'd be most likely to find justice.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Imagine we're painting a statue and someone says, 'Why didn't you make the eyes purple? They'd look more beautiful!' The eyes are the best part!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We'd tell them: 'We're not trying to make the eyes so beautiful they stop looking like eyes. We're making the whole thing beautiful by giving each part its proper role.'

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There are two things that ruin craftsmanship.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What are they?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Being too rich or too poor.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: How so?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When a potter gets rich, do you think he'll still work as hard at his craft?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Definitely not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He gets lazy and careless, and becomes a worse potter. But if he's too poor and can't afford good tools, his work suffers too.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's obvious.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So here's another thing guardians need to watch out for—wealth and poverty. One breeds laziness and luxury, the other breeds desperation and crime. Both cause problems.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But how will our city fight wars against rich, powerful enemies if we don't have money?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Fighting one rich enemy would be tough. But what if there are two of them?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First, our side would be trained warriors fighting against rich amateurs.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Don't you think one skilled boxer could beat two wealthy guys who've never trained?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Maybe not if they attacked at the same time.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What if he could retreat, then turn and strike the first one who catches up? Do that a few times in the hot sun, and couldn't he take them both down?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yeah, that would work.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So our athletes could probably handle two or three times their number?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I think you're right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's the thing—every city, no matter how small, is actually two cities: one of the rich, one of the poor. They're always at war with each other.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If you play them against each other, you'll always have lots of allies and few enemies.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What's the ideal size for our state?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What would you suggest?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: As big as it can be while still staying unified. That's the limit.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Education is key. If our citizens are well-educated and sensible, they'll figure out the rest.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A well-started state builds momentum like a wheel. Good education creates good character, and good character makes the next generation's education even better.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Probably true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The most important thing is keeping music and physical education unchanged. No innovations.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When musical styles change, the fundamental laws of the state change with them. It's dangerous.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I agree with that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So our guardians need to build their fortress on music?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yeah, because lawlessness creeps in so easily.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It starts as entertainment and seems harmless.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Right, but gradually this spirit of 'anything goes' spreads into customs, then into business dealings, then into laws, until eventually it destroys everything—public and private.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is that really true?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's what I believe.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, but where's justice in all this? Now that we've built our city, let's search for it. Get your brother and Polemarchus and everyone else to help.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Wait, didn't you promise to search yourself? You said it would be wrong not to help justice when she needs it!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Fair point. I'll keep my word, but you have to help.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Deal.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay, here's my approach: let's assume our state, if properly organized, is perfect.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if it's perfect, it must be wise, brave, temperate, and just.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First virtue: wisdom. Our state is wise because it has good judgment.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And good judgment comes from knowledge, not ignorance.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But a carpenter's knowledge doesn't make a city wise—that just makes it good at carpentry.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Right, that would just give it a reputation for building stuff.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is there any knowledge that considers the whole state and how it should deal with itself and other states?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What is it and who has it?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: It's the knowledge of the guardians—the ones we called perfect guardians.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So we've found one of the four virtues.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And pretty satisfactorily, I'd say.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Courage is easier to spot. When we call a state brave or cowardly, we're thinking of its military.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A state is brave because of the people who fight for it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Courage is preserving what education taught you about what's truly dangerous—keeping that belief through pleasure, pain, desire, and fear.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Think about dyeing wool. Dyers start with white wool and prepare it carefully so the purple dye holds perfectly and won't wash out.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, if you don't prepare it right, the color looks faded and ridiculous.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's exactly what we were doing with our soldiers—preparing them through music and exercise so the 'dye' of our laws would hold permanently.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I get it. You're distinguishing real courage from the wild instinct of animals or slaves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Exactly. Two virtues down. Now we need temperance, and then justice—the whole point of our search.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can we find justice without figuring out temperance first?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I don't think so. I'd rather you explain temperance first so we don't lose track of it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Fair enough. Temperance is about controlling your desires. That's what people mean when they say someone is 'master of themselves.'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But 'master of yourself' is kind of a weird phrase, right? The master is also the servant?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What it really means is that there's a better part and a worse part in your soul. When the better part controls the worse, you're 'master of yourself.'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That makes more sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Unlike courage and wisdom, which each belong to one part, temperance runs through the whole thing—like a harmony that connects all the different parts.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I totally agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So that's three virtues. The last one—justice—is what we've been hunting for this whole time.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Okay Glaucon, it's hunting time. We need to surround this thing and make sure justice doesn't escape.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I wish I could help more, but I'm just following your lead here.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Say a prayer and follow me.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I will, but you have to show me where to go.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's no clear path and it's dark and confusing, but we have to push through.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Wait—I see something! I think I've got a trail. The prey won't escape now.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's great!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Man, we're such idiots. Justice was right under our feet this whole time and we never noticed.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Remember the principle we kept coming back to when building the state? That each person should do one thing—the thing they're naturally best at. That's justice, or at least part of it.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, we said that a lot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We also said justice is doing your own work and not meddling in other people's business.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: We did say that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So when traders, soldiers, and guardians each do their own job, that's justice—that's what makes a city just.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Don't you think the same principles exist in individual people as in the state?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's not hard to see.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But here's the tricky part: are these principles three separate things, or one? Do we learn with one part of ourselves, get angry with another, and desire things with a third?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, that's the hard question.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The same thing can't do opposite things at the same time in the same way.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So we can assume there are two parts: a rational part that reasons, and an irrational part that hungers and desires.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That seems fair.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But what about passion or spirit? Is that a third thing, or is it part of desire?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I'd guess it's related to desire.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me tell you a story. Leontius was walking up from the port and saw some executed bodies on the ground. He wanted to look at them but also felt disgusted.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He struggled for a while, covering his eyes. But finally the desire won—he ran over and said, 'There! Look at the beautiful sight, you wretches!'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I've heard that story.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The point is that anger fought against desire—they're two different things.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, that's what it shows.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So after all that, we've landed on this: the same three principles that exist in the state also exist in each person.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So an individual is wise in the same way and for the same reason a state is wise?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And a person is just in the same way a state is just?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That follows.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A just person doesn't let the different parts of their soul interfere with each other. They organize their inner life, become their own master, and are at peace with themselves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When they've harmonized their three inner parts—like the high, low, and middle notes of a scale—then they act. And they call whatever maintains this harmony 'just and good.'

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's exactly right, Socrates.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So virtue is the health and beauty of the soul, and vice is its disease and ugliness.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Good habits lead to virtue, bad habits to vice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We still haven't answered our original question though: which is more profitable, justice or injustice?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Honestly Socrates, that question seems ridiculous now. If your body is ruined, life isn't worth living no matter how much money you have. So if your soul is corrupted, how could life be worth living?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You're right, it is ridiculous. But since we're so close to seeing the truth clearly, let's not give up now.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: From up here, we can see that virtue is one thing, but vice comes in countless forms—four especially worth noting.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There are as many types of souls as there are types of governments.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How many?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Five types of states, five types of souls. The first is what we've been describing—call it monarchy or aristocracy, depending on whether one person or many rule.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.
